snippet: When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel last Thursday, he did not know that a German intelligence operative had been arrested a day earlier, and had admitted to passing secrets to the C.I.A.
abstract: White House officials are questioning who in the Central Intelligence Agency knew that its German intelligence operative had been compromised, and why Pres Obama was not made aware of case before he made a call to German Chancellor Angela Merkel; fact that Obama was kept in the dark about the blown spying operation sheds light on tensions arising from collisions of spycraft and statecraft.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and MARK LANDLER

lead_paragraph: When President Obama placed a call to Chancellor Angela Merkel last Thursday, he did not know that a German intelligence operative had been arrested a day earlier, and had admitted to passing secrets to the C.I.A.

headline.main: Spying Case Left Obama in Dark, U.S. Officials Say
headline.print_headline: Spying Case Left Obama in Dark, U.S. Officials Say
